column4: How can I set up automatically opening of a encrypted disk in this new fast-booting karmic? When booting without quiet and splash, the last thing i see befor the login manager kicks off is "Enter password for the disk DATA:" but it doesnt really give me a chance..
you don't want it to automatically mount an encrypted drive
I want it to if it asks me the password first
the passphrase would have to be stored plaintext for any utility to use it, defeating the purpose
That is why i want it to ask me to input it first
you have a partition that is encrypted, OTHER than the root partition?
Yes, i have
good question... i encrypt everything except /boot, so it HAS to stop and ask me for passphrase
I did that in 9.04 too, but i figured that the only thing I need to encrypt is the /home/ folder, since the rest is open source anyway. So I only encrypt swap and /home/
i'm not sure about the implementation in linux, but sometimes the passphrase can be recovered from swap
it's known as the cold boot attack
that is why I encrypt swap aswell ;)
Its hard to read something when the key is generated on boot for each session by /dev/urandom :-P
are both home and swap on the same crypto disk?
nope, different partitions, it would defeat the purpose of encryption if you can
i'd hate to have to put in multiple passphrases EVERY single boot
the way i have it set up is with 2 logical partitions, boot and crypt. on the crypto disk i have an lvm disk, and on that i have swap and /

That is why I encrypted root and home with 2048bit generated keys and added them to a small keys partition which I had a script decrypt the keys partition, then use the keys in that partition to open the home and root partition, then I closed the keys partition before booting.
There is no reason not to encrypt swap as a seperate partition with a generated key for each boot. Adds a layer of security
Should do the same with /tmp rly, but im not sure how much space you would need on tmp...
i have to admit, i'm a little bit lost by your setup. i'm sorry i can't be of more help
np :)
